results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to extend Knowledge Tracing (KT) for open-ended coding questions, incorporating test case-level information. It details the development of a new KT task and a method called TIKTOC.
Sections 3.1 and 4.3 provide a detailed formulation of the problem and a step-by-step description of the TIKTOC method, including its components and training process.
The document states: "We augment the CodeWorkout dataset [8] with the test cases used for a subset of the questions. We have publicly released this augmented dataset to serve as a benchmark..."
The data is stated to be publicly released, so justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
Table 2 provides statistics of the augmented dataset, and the document references the CodeWorkout dataset's documentation on PSLC DataShop [8].

The document describes the data collection process, stating it comes from an introductory Java programming course at a large US university and details the types of test cases extracted from CodeWorkout.
The document does not explicitly state that the analysis code is shared in an open repository.
Since the code is not stated to be shared, justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
The document mentions an automated evaluation pipeline for data preparation but does not state whether the code for this pipeline is shared.
The document describes the statistical metrics used for evaluation (AUC, F1 Score, accuracy, CodeBLEU) and mentions the use of LSTM networks and multi-task learning.
The document reports performance metrics with standard deviations and mentions statistical significance testing (p-values).
The document includes qualitative case studies (Tables 5, 6, and 7) with interpretations of the model's behavior and insights into student learning.
While qualitative analysis is present, the document does not explicitly describe a formal data coding or analysis process for the case studies.
Results are presented in tables (3, 4, 5, 6, 7) with clear comparisons between different methods.
The document discusses limitations in the final section, including the need to explore ways to leverage test case content and address fairness concerns.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
